fields.summary: Ephemeral space formatting does not match AWS

fields.summary: EBS-backed Instance block device "ephemeral" not formatted to ext3

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
*Assessment*

Per [AWS documentation regarding Instance Storage|http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/InstanceStorage.html#InstanceStoreDeviceNames]:

{quote}
Within an instance store, instance store volumes are exposed as block devices. The virtual devices for instance store volumes are ephemeral\[0-3\]. Instance types that support one instance store volume have ephemeral0. Instance types that support two instance store volumes have ephemeral0 and ephemeral1. Instance types that support four instance store volumes have ephemeral0, ephemeral1, ephemeral2, and ephemeral3. *Each instance store volume is pre-formatted with the ext3 file system*. However, you can reformat volumes with the file system of your choice after you launch your instance. *A Windows instance uses a built-in tool, EC2Config Service, to reformat the instance store volumes available on an instance with the NTFS file system*.
{quote}

This isn't the case as seen with instance store-backed instances on Eucalyptus 4.0 (4.0.0-0.0.867.20140411git0cd00881.el6.x86_64).  Below shows the format of the /dev/vdb device:
{code}
[root@odc-d-31 ~]# euca-describe-instances
RESERVATION	r-e912dcad	408181979667	default
INSTANCE	i-91b16494	emi-2d8fd091	10.104.6.230	172.18.0.119	running	euca-admin	0		m1.xlarge	2014-04-11T15:50:24.171Z	GiftOfGab2				monitoring-disabled	10.104.6.230	172.18.0.119			instance-store					hvm			sg-3331a047
TAG	instance	i-91b16494	euca:node	10.104.1.188

[root@odc-d-31 ~]# euca-describe-images emi-2d8fd091
IMAGE	emi-2d8fd091	408181979667/trusty-x86_64-hvm	408181979667	available	private	x86_64	machine				instance-store	hvm

### From within the instance ###

ubuntu@ip-172-18-0-119:~$ ls /dev/vd*
/dev/vda  /dev/vda1  /dev/vdb

ubuntu@ip-172-18-0-119:~$ dmesg | grep vda
[    0.401344]  vda: vda1
[    1.768343] EXT4-fs (vda1): mounted filesystem with ordered data mode. Opts: (null)
[    1.984014] EXT4-fs (vda1): re-mounted. Opts: (null)
[   29.550244] EXT4-fs (vda1): resizing filesystem from 360448 to 576256 blocks
[   29.550334] EXT4-fs (vda1): resized filesystem to 576256
ubuntu@ip-172-18-0-119:~$ dmesg | grep vdb
[    0.417780]  vdb: unknown partition table

root@ip-172-18-0-119:~# parted /dev/vdb
GNU Parted 2.3
Using /dev/vdb
Welcome to GNU Parted! Type 'help' to view a list of commands.
(parted) p
Error: /dev/vdb: unrecognised disk label
(parted)
{code}

On AWS, ephemeral is formatted:

{code}
### from within an HVM instance ###
$ aws ec2 describe-images --image-ids ami-994b5ef0 --profile harold-work --output text
IMAGES	x86_64	Amazon Linux AMI x86_64 HVM S3	xen	ami-994b5ef0	amzn-ami-us-east-1/amzn-ami-hvm-2014.03.rc-1.x86_64.manifest.xml	amazon	machine	amzn-ami-hvm-2014.03.rc-1.x86_64-s3	137112412989	True	instance-store	simple	available	hvm

[ec2-user@ip-10-65-4-19 ~]$ ls /dev/xvd*
/dev/xvda  /dev/xvda1  /dev/xvdb

[root@ip-10-65-4-19 ec2-user]# parted /dev/xvdb
GNU Parted 2.1
Using /dev/xvdb
Welcome to GNU Parted! Type 'help' to view a list of commands.
(parted) p
Model: Xen Virtual Block Device (xvd)
Disk /dev/xvdb: 32.2GB
Sector size (logical/physical): 512B/512B
Partition Table: loop

Number  Start  End     Size    File system  Flags
 1      0.00B  32.2GB  32.2GB  ext3
{code}

This breaks AWS compatibility and effects bootstrapping mechanisms like cloud-init. 

In 3.4.2, for paravirtual instance store-backed instances, ephemeral would be formatted as ext3 - per AWS behavior - so I am not sure if this should be considered a regression or not:

{code}
RESERVATION	r-EF1A4A19	441445882805	default
INSTANCE	i-E1204160	emi-18F43354	euca-10-104-7-10.eucalyptus.euca-hasp.eucalyptus-systems.com	euca-172-17-111-204.eucalyptus.internal	running	euca-admin	0		m1.medium	2014-04-11T00:09:03.357Z	LayinDaSmackDown	eki-19733665	eri-ACEE395D		monitoring-disabled	10.104.7.10	172.17.111.204			instance-store					paravirtualized
TAG	instance	i-E1204160	euca:node	node1

$ euca-describe-images emi-18F43354 --region admin@
IMAGE	emi-18F43354	opensuse12.2-x86_64-old/opensuse-12.2-x86_64-emi.img.manifest.xml	441445882805	available	private	x86_64	machine	eki-19733665	eri-ACEE395D		instance-store	paravirtualized

euca-172-17-111-204:~ # curl http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/block-device-mapping/ephemeral0
sda2

euca-172-17-111-204:~ # parted /dev/vda2 print
Model: Virtio Block Device (virtblk)
Disk /dev/vda2: 13.2GB
Sector size (logical/physical): 512B/512B
Partition Table: loop

Number  Start  End     Size    File system  Flags
 1      0.00B  13.2GB  13.2GB  ext3
{code}

*Signs*

In the nc.log, it can be seen that the NC allocates the ephemeral space, but doesn't format it:
{code}
2014-04-11 08:50:28  INFO 000027202 doRunInstance            | [i-91b16494] running instance cores=2 disk=10 memory=1024 vlan=-1 net=-1 priMAC=d0:0d:91:b1:64:94 privIp=172.18.0.119 plat=linux kernel=(null) ramdisk=(null)
2014-04-11 08:50:28 DEBUG 000027202 vbr_legacy               | [i-91b16494]                VBR[0] type=ephemeral id=none dev=sdb size=8376025088 format=none none
2014-04-11 08:50:28 DEBUG 000027202 vbr_legacy               | [i-91b16494]                VBR[1] type=machine id=emi-2d8fd091 dev=sda size=2361393152 format=none http://imaging@10.104.1.194:8773/services/objectstorage/5922c0-download-manifests/DM-r-e912dcad?Expires=1397242224&AWSAccessKeyId=AKIHTMNYTRQ0MIHQAKEY&Signature=Hf0QTXXrP7D03rWhOG3iwq0hiO8%3D
2014-04-11 08:50:28 DEBUG 000027202 change_state             | [i-91b16494] state change for instance: Unknown -> Staging (Pending)
2014-04-11 08:50:28 DEBUG 000030797 startup_thread           | [i-91b16494] spawning startup thread
2014-04-11 08:50:28  INFO 000030797 ensure_directories_exist | creating path /var/lib/eucalyptus/instances/work/AIDM6JWCJGSTODHZBNHND/i-91b16494
2014-04-11 08:50:28 DEBUG 000030797 diskutil_ch              | ch(own|mod) '/var/lib/eucalyptus/instances/work/AIDM6JWCJGSTODHZBNHND/i-91b16494' *.root 771
2014-04-11 08:50:28 DEBUG 000030797 vbr_alloc_tree           | [i-91b16494] found 0 prereqs and 2 partitions/disks in the VBR
2014-04-11 08:50:28 DEBUG 000030797 art_alloc                | [i-91b16494] allocated artifact 006|i-91b16494 size=-1 vbr=(nil) cache=0 file=0
2014-04-11 08:50:29 DEBUG 000030797 art_alloc                | [i-91b16494] allocated artifact 007|emi-2d8fd091-e214a630 size=2361393152 vbr=0x7fece2b36c80 cache=1 file=0

fields.summary: Instances Ephemeral Storage is not formatted ext3

comments.body:
Per confirmation with [~spark], the Eucalyptus Windows Integration Tool does format the ephemeral storage to NTFS, just like the AWS EC2Config tool.

https://github.com/eucalyptus/windows-integration/blob/master/EucaServiceLibrary/EucaServiceLibrary.cs#L925-L961

We now format the ephemeral storage for hvm as ext3.

{code}
ubuntu@euca-172-28-167-125:~$ dmesg | grep vdb
[    0.265667]  vdb: unknown partition table
ubuntu@euca-172-28-167-125:~$ sudo parted /dev/vdb
sudo: unable to resolve host euca-172-28-167-125
GNU Parted 2.3
Using /dev/vdb
Welcome to GNU Parted! Type 'help' to view a list of commands.
(parted) p                                                                
Model: Virtio Block Device (virtblk)
Disk /dev/vdb: 3221MB
Sector size (logical/physical): 512B/512B
Partition Table: loop

Hey [~tony],

I was testing this out on the [Group #1 cloud|https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/wiki/display/QA/Euca+4.1+Quality+Dashboard#Euca4.1QualityDashboard-Group#1] using EBS-backed instances that had a block-device-mapping where ephemeral0 was assigned to a particular device.  The metadata information in the EBS-backed instance was correct (per the fix in EUCA-7860), however the ephemeral device was not formatted to ext3.

{code}
ubuntu@euca-10-111-52-182:~$ curl http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/block-device-mapping/; echo
ami
emi
ephemeral0
root
ubuntu@euca-10-111-52-182:~$ curl http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/block-device-mapping/ephemeral0; echo
sdc
ubuntu@euca-10-111-52-182:~$ ls /dev/vd*
/dev/vda  /dev/vda1  /dev/vdb
ubuntu@euca-10-111-52-182:~$ sudo parted /dev/vdb print
Error: /dev/vdb: unrecognised disk label
ubuntu@euca-10-111-52-182:~$ sudo parted /dev/vda1 print
Model: Virtio Block Device (virtblk)
Disk /dev/vda1: 7515MB
Sector size (logical/physical): 512B/512B
Partition Table: loop

Number  Start  End     Size    File system  Flags
 1      0.00B  7515MB  7515MB  ext4
{code}

*Steps*

# Create EBS-backed EMI using existing instance store-backed EMI on [Group #1 cloud|https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/wiki/display/QA/Euca+4.1+Quality+Dashboard#Euca4.1QualityDashboard-Group#1] - ([Ubuntu example can be seen in the KB articles|https://support.eucalyptus.com/hc/en-us/articles/201605884-Creating-an-Ubuntu-EBS-backed-EMI-from-an-Existing-Instance-Store-Backed-Instance])
# Launch an EBS-backed instance from the EBS-backed EMI.  For example:
{code}
# euca-describe-images --region admin-hspencer@group1
IMAGE	emi-1bb60055	661782123396/ubuntu-trusty-x86_64-ebs-hvm	661782123396	available	private	x86_64	machine				ebs	hvm
BLOCKDEVICEMAPPING	EBS	/dev/sda	snap-203ff37f	7	true	standard
IMAGE	emi-8ad9dddb	ubuntu-trusty-20150120/trusty-server-cloudimg-amd64-disk1-20150115.img.manifest.xml	661782123396	available	private	x86_64	machine				instance-store	hvm

# euca-run-instances -k admin-hspencer1 -t m1.large emi-1bb60055 -z two --block-device-mapping=/dev/sdc=ephemeral0 --region admin-hspencer@group1
{code}
# Confirm block device mapping returned in metadata service:
{code}
ubuntu@euca-10-111-52-182:~$ curl http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/block-device-mapping/; echo
ami
emi
ephemeral0
root
ubuntu@euca-10-111-52-182:~$ curl http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/block-device-mapping/ephemeral0; echo
sdc
ubuntu@euca-10-111-52-182:~$ ls /dev/vd*
/dev/vda  /dev/vda1  /dev/vdb
ubuntu@euca-10-111-52-182:~$ ls /dev/sd*
ls: cannot access /dev/sd*: No such file or directory
{code}
# Confirm format of ephemeral storage (should be ext3):
{code}
ubuntu@euca-10-111-52-182:~$ sudo parted /dev/vdb print
Error: /dev/vdb: unrecognised disk label
{code}
[~hspencer], the fix in 4.0 for this was for instance-store instances rather than ebs.

[~sjones],

Ok, I will raise another ticket and close this one out.  Thanks.
Issue was fixed for instance store-backed instances, but not for EBS-backed instances.  Raised EUCA-10502 and linked it accordingly.
